text: and maybe ForwardDiff2's `D` object
sounds doable

Also got to have test suites so can be certain everything implements API the same.

I would also suggest that such test-suite should use reflection to ensure that  extra kwarg and positional args that are not common to everything are not present
So that changing ADs is just a matter of changing out an object that holds *everything* that makes an AD special.
(including e.g. caches if its using its own special caches)

text: In the directional derivative function, what’s the generalisation of `dot`? I am trying to define a default implementation that assumes `dot` has been defined for the direction and function output spaces. Is this reasonable?

dot is a linear operator.

text: Nice thing about `dot`  for cross-promotion is that can say something like _“for X to work from you only defining A,B,C, then your method for A must return something that implements `dot` , e.g. a number, a matrix, or a ChainRulesCore differential. Otherwise you can define X directly”_

, e.g. a number, a matrix, or a ChainRulesCore differential. Otherwise you can define X directly”

text:
So it seems that if an AD package defines `jacobian` and `primalvalue`, all the remaining AD functionality can be derived from those 2 operations. For example, `value_and_jacobian` is:
```function value_and_jacobian(ab::AbstractBackend, f, xs...)
    local value
    jacs = jacobian(ab, (xs...,) -> begin
        v = f(xs...)
        value = primalvalue(v)
        return v
    end, xs...)
    return value, jacs
end```
Similarly, `value_and_pullback_function` and `value_and_pushforward_function` can be defined in a backend-agnostic way using only `jacobian` and `primalvalue`.

elements.text: So it seems that if an AD package defines

text: Similarly, `derivative` and `gradient` are special `jacobian`s. `hessian` is the jacobian of the gradient.

elements.text: is the jacobian of the gradient.

text:
Everything can also be derived from `value_and_pullback_function`
since you just stack on columns to make jacobians

similar for pushforward

text: True but `jacobian` and `primalvalue` are simpler concepts than `value_and_pullback_function`.
So I think it makes sense to define the complex in terms of the simple, not the other way around if both are possible.

elements.text: So I think it makes sense to define the complex in terms of the simple, not the other way around if both are possible.

text: Of course internally `jacobian` can be calling a package’s `value_and_pullback_function` equivalent, because you know chain rules…

elements.text: equivalent, because you know chain rules…

not simpler to me, but maybe i broke my mind.

We should, I think, have jacobian fallback to them. Fiddly to avoid an infinite loop but I think we can do it.
